general topics.__EMPTY_1: useState is a React Hook that allows components to persist data across renders. It triggers a UI update whenever its value changes by comparing the old and new memory references. It supports direct values, functional updates for stale data protection, and lazy initialization for performance-heavy tasks.

Vite (French for "fast") is a modern frontend build tool designed to replace older, slower bundlers like Webpack. It significantly speeds up the development process by using a "no-bundle" approach during development—leveraging Native ES Modules (ESM) to serve files directly to the browser. In production, it uses Rollup to create a highly optimized, minified bundle of your code.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Details
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Benefit

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Uses esbuild (written in Go) to pre-bundle dependencies 10–100x faster than JS bundlers.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: No more waiting for your dev server to start up.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Swaps updated modules without reloading the whole page or losing useState.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Near-instant feedback loop when you save a file.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Serves source code over native ESM, letting the browser do the bundling work in dev.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Performance remains fast even as your project grows.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Automatically handles image hashing, CSS code-splitting, and URL inlining.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Smaller production builds and better browser caching.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Native support for TypeScript, JSX, CSS Modules, and Tailwind CSS.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Zero-config setup for most modern React projects.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Uses import.meta.env instead of process.env for typed variables.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: More secure and easier to manage in modern JS/TS.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Uses Rollup under the hood for sophisticated tree-shaking and multi-page support.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: High-performance final code for your Node/Web server.

general topics.__EMPTY_1: CRA is a CLI tool that sets up a React project with a single dependency: react-scripts. It is "opinionated," meaning it makes all the configuration decisions for you. However, it has become much slower than Vite because it relies on Webpack, which bundles your entire application before the dev server can even start.

Uses Rollup under the hood for sophisticated tree-shaking and multi-page support.

general topics.__EMPTY_1: esbuild is an extremely fast JavaScript bundler and minifier written in Go. Its primary goal is to bring a new era of performance to frontend tooling. Unlike traditional bundlers (Webpack, Rollup) written in JavaScript, esbuild is compiled to native machine code, allowing it to perform 10x to 100x faster by utilizing parallelization and efficient memory management.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Details
Written in Go; bypasses the performance bottlenecks of the Node.js runtime.
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Sub-second builds even for large projects.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Fully utilizes all available CPU cores to process files in parallel.
Built-in support for transpiling .ts, .tsx, and .jsx without external plugins.
general topics.__EMPTY_3: No need for Babel for standard syntax transformations.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Automatically removes unused code from your final production bundle.
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Resulting files are smaller and faster for users to download.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Combines multiple files into one and shrinks the code (removing whitespace/shortening variables).
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Optimized "Build" output ready for production servers.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Allows developers to hook into the build process (e.g., for specialized CSS handling).
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Highly extensible if you need to go beyond standard JS/TS.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Can bundle code for the Browser (ESM) or Node.js (CommonJS).
general topics.__EMPTY_3: A single tool for both your Frontend and Backend compilation.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Manage State
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Returns a state value and a function to update it.

general topics.__EMPTY_5: Avoids passing props through 10 layers of components.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Complex State
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Manages state via "Actions" and a "Reducer" function.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Shopping carts, complex forms, Redux-style logic.
general topics.__EMPTY_5: Centralizes logic; makes state changes predictable.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Persistent Ref
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Holds a value that doesn't trigger a re-render when changed.

general topics.__EMPTY_3: Caches the result of an expensive calculation.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Filtering large arrays, heavy math transformations.
general topics.__EMPTY_5: Prevents lagging by skipping unnecessary calculations.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Memoize Func
general topics.__EMPTY_3: Caches a function definition between renders.
general topics.__EMPTY_4: Passing functions to optimized child components.
general topics.__EMPTY_5: Prevents child components from re-rendering for no reason.

general topics.__EMPTY_2: Description
The top-level wrapper that enables navigation features throughout your app. It syncs the UI with the URL.
Routes is the container that looks at the URL; Route defines the relationship between a URL path and a Component.
Components used to navigate without refreshing the page. NavLink automatically adds an .active class for styling.
A hook to access dynamic segments of the URL (like IDs or usernames) within your component.
general topics.__EMPTY_3:
const { id } = useParams();

// URL: /user/42 -> id is 42

general topics.__EMPTY_2: A hook that returns a function for programmatic navigation (e.g., redirecting after a form submission).
A placeholder component that renders the child route's element within a parent route's layout.
A special prop on a child Route that makes it the default view when the user is at the parent path.
Used to read and modify the query string (the part after the ? in a URL). Works like useState.
A component version of useNavigate. It is often used for redirects in "Protected Routes."
Returns the current location object, containing the pathname, hash, and any "state" passed during navigation.
Used to catch any URL that doesn't match your defined routes—perfect for "404 Not Found" pages.
